posts.name:
All India EV
All India EV
posts.content:
𝐌𝐚𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐫𝐚 𝐭𝐨 𝐑𝐞𝐯𝐨𝐥𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐳𝐞 𝐄𝐕 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐮𝐟𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐍𝐞𝐰 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐤𝐚𝐧 𝐏𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐭 

𝐌𝐚𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐫𝐚 𝐄𝐥𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐜 𝐀𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐞𝐬 𝐋𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐞𝐝 (𝐌𝐄𝐀𝐋) is all set to begin production at its 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐞-𝐨𝐟-𝐭𝐡𝐞-𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐤𝐚𝐧 𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐮𝐟𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐛𝐲 𝐐𝟒 𝐅𝐘𝟐𝟓. The facility will produce Mahindra’s cutting-edge INGLO platform-based Born Electric SUVs, including the 𝐗𝐔𝐕.𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐁𝐄 𝐬𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬.

, President of 𝐌𝐚𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐫𝐚 𝐀𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞, highlighted that the 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐤𝐚𝐧 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐭 will play a pivotal role in the company’s EV strategy, ensuring strong local manufacturing capabilities to cater to India's growing demand for electric SUVs.

With ₹𝟏𝟎,𝟎𝟎𝟎 𝐜𝐫𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐧 𝐌𝐚𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐬𝐡𝐭𝐫𝐚, 𝐌𝐚𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐫𝐚 is making significant strides in creating an indigenous 𝐄𝐕 𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐬𝐲𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐦. The new plant will also focus on battery assembly, contributing to sustainable EV solutions and meeting future emission norms.

 𝐌𝐚𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐫𝐚 𝐢𝐬 𝐝𝐫𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐟𝐮𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐬𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐦𝐨𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐢𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐈𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐚’𝐬 𝐄𝐕 𝐫𝐞𝐯𝐨𝐥𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧!

comments.commentText: My only concern is sub standard manifacturing practices currently we have in our country perticularly regarding Battery manifacturing and testing. Be it leak test, high voltage test....if they adress it with correct technology then its a all together a complete bussiness vertical in itself....finger cross
Seems Good... Also, prioritize services to your customers in future ahead to sustain long term growth and satisfaction.

posts.name:
Troy Leach
Troy Leach
posts.content:
Appreciate the opportunity to come speak in 
#Dubai this week for CSA STAR Auditor ControlCase at their 14th Annual Global Conference.

I will be discussing with bank CISOs and other
leaders in the region about the risks, regulation and resiliency that GenAI and cloud services present and strategies to manage the opportunities with modernized risk management practices.

Will also be sharing more about theAI Controls Matrix (out for peer review currently) and how we envision continuous assurance and automation for compliance in the near future with upcoming 2025 programs.

Appreciate the hospitality byand look forward to seeing my former colleaguespeak on the latest updates to PCI standards.

comments.commentText: Thank you Troy Leach. I am Looking forward to interacting with you in Dubai this week. PCI Security Standards Council
Interesting event

posts.name:
Kyle Asay
Kyle Asay
posts.content:
I responded to a cold email: “This isn’t my priority. Best of luck with your outreach!”

Got hit with an objection handle: “Just to confirm - closing more deals faster isn’t a priority?”

I get the approach: The idea is to “trap” the prospect into a question they can’t say no to.

“What sales leader wouldn’t want more deals, faster?”

Here’s the problem: I’m not objecting to the proposed outcome. Closing more deals faster is ALWAYS a priority for me.

I’m just already working on my top priorities to help my teams close more deals faster. We’ve identified tools supporting those priorities and are in execution mode.

My objection wasn’t to the outcome. It was the approach this solution takes to drive that outcome. The problems they solve to drive that outcome are not painful for me.

When you get a no, don’t fall back to the high-level outcome:

- “Oh, you don’t want to save money on your HR solutions?”

- “Really, you don’t want to reduce the risk of getting hacked?”

- “Huh, you don’t want your developers to be happy and productive?”

Of course your buyers want those outcomes. If they are objecting, they likely either:

- Don’t believe you can drive that outcome

- Believe a different approach will work better

Find out which of those your objection falls under and address that for better success.

Here’s what that follow-up might look like:

“Makes perfect sense you’ve already got a handle on this. Usually this means you’ve got a similar solution in place and I didn’t do a good job sharing how we are different, or you are attacking this priority through a completely different approach.

Can I ask where you fall?”

Next time you hear “this isn’t a priority” to something that you know should be a priority, give this a shot!

comments.commentText: right on! the classic trap question can backfire when you're not addressing the real reason behind the objection
Gotta understand before you “trap”

posts.name:
Kesari Sai Sabniveesu
Kesari Sai Sabniveesu
posts.content:
From Data to Delivery: Mastering ERP-3PL Integration

Building on my earlier discussion about ERP-3PL integrations, I’m excited to share a comprehensive overview enriched by practical knowledge and hands-on experience gained from collaborating with multiple clients across various industries and geographies.
This overview will delve into effective integration strategies, illuminate best practices, and explore the challenges and solutions that come with integrating ERP systems with 3PL providers.

My goal is to create a deeper understanding of these integrations while inviting fellow professionals to collaborate, share insights, and contribute to a continuous learning process. Together, we can uncover innovative approaches, refine methodologies, and drive greater efficiency in ERP-3PL integration projects.

I look forward to engaging discussions and the opportunity to exchange ideas that benefit the broader ERP and logistics communities.

comments.commentText: Very informative Kesari Sai Sabniveesu
Jatin Tiwari Thank you

posts.name:
Bhushan Parikh
Bhushan Parikh
posts.content: We have been hearing a lot about working hours from some of the Industry greats from India. Last I counted we were between 70 - 90 hours per week and asked to work instead of staring at our wives on the weekend. I was waiting to see to who would catch the fundamental mistake in this thought process and call it. And the winner is - Anand Mahindra, Chairperson of the Board of Mahindra Group! He called it in three simple words - Quality over Quantity!

comments.commentText: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/economictimes_wife-love-staring-activity-7284075162726023169-QBF8?utm_medium=ios_app&utm_source=social_share_video_v2&utm_campaign=copy_link

Your insights on work-life balance resonate deeply, Bhushan. Quality over quantity is a vital mindset shift in today's fast-paced world, and I appreciate you highlighting Anand Mahindra's perspective.

posts.name:
Brandon Fluharty
Brandon Fluharty
posts.content:
7 years ago I left a comfortable Enterprise AE role at a late-stage startup where I was a top performer to join a new, but unknown, Strategic Account team. 

I was the only person on that small team to hit their number that year.

I went on to average $1.07M in personal annual earnings each year for the following 3 years.

Luck? Good timing? Great product? Solid team?

Yes to all of those.

But … I was also extremely purposeful with my performance, and it paid off (literally).

These were the 5 high-leverage moves I made in my first year that set the foundation for earning life-changing wealth in my 4 year tenure there:

1. Thought like a CEO

2. Was disciplined with my “launch strategy”

3. Made my account list mean something to me

4. Didn’t wait to have real business conversations

5. Thought more like a creative content creator

I break down all 5 of these in a free guide:

It’s a new year.

Perhaps it’s time for a new way to operate?

comments.commentText: Love how intentional you were with your moves
Tom Alder Intentionality is the first step to Independence.
Moving with purpose every single day requires finding those high leverage activities that move the needle and keep us out of feeling busy
Jeff Riseley And that first takes getting clear on what they are for you (not just other people's voices in your head creating unnecessary noise and confusion).
